translated: Jātaka🔽The Minor Collection🔽The Chapter with Pairs
The Story of the Beggar’s Successive Meals
“Having seen a beautiful form,
I left the country and went to the forest.
I slept on a great bed
with the appearance of a stilt house.
I gave you a meal of rice and curries
with a side dish of meat.
It was rice from the best fields,
well-cooked and clean.
You accepted that meal
and gave it to the brahmin.
You didn’t eat it yourself.
What is this quality of yours?”
“The brahmin is my teacher,
and he is busy with his duties.
He is respected and worthy of being invited,
and so I give him food.”
“I now ask the brahmin Gotama,
who is honored by the king:
The king gave you a meal
with a side dish of meat.
You accepted that meal
and gave it to the ascetic.
You don’t know the field of generosity.
What is this quality of yours?”
“I support my wife and children,
and I’m attached to my home.
I enjoy human sensual pleasures,
I give advice to the king.
To the sage who lives in the wilderness,
who has practiced austerities for a long time;
To the elder who is developed,
I am able to give food.”
“Now I ask the sage,
why are you so thin and bony?
Your hair and nails are overgrown,
your teeth are stained, and your head is grey.
You live alone in the wilderness,
you have no concern for life;
What monk is better than you,
to whom you give food?”
“Digging up wild tubers,
and picking wild jujubes;
Shaking the sāka, sāma, and nivāra,

translated: Cooking for one who does not cook,🔽without possessions, with possessions;
For one who does not accept, I accept,
I am able to give food.”
“Now I ask the monk,
who is sitting silently, Subbata;
The sage offered you food,
pure with meat as a condiment.
Having accepted that food,
You eat alone in silence,
You don’t invite anyone else.
What is this quality of yours? I pay homage to you.”
“I don’t cook or have others cook.

analyzed: sabba pāpehi ārata  vāmena bhikkham ādāya
translated: free from all evil,🔽taking my almsfood in my left hand
and my water pot in my right,
the sage offered me food,
pure and seasoned with meat.
They are able to give,
with their equals and their retinue.
I think I’m their enemy,
who invites the one who gives.”
“Today, indeed, for my sake,
the lord of the chariot has come here.
Today I understand
where what is given bears great fruit.
Kings are greedy for countries,
Brahmins for business and non-business.
Seers are greedy for roots and fruits,
while the monks are free.”
The Thirteenth Portion is concluded.🔽The Pakiṇṇaka Collection is finished.
